#Text=XI
#Text=When Diotti and old Sanders left the house they walked rapidly down Fifth Avenue .
#Text=It was after eleven , and the streets were bare of pedestrians , but blinking-eyed cabs came up the avenue , looking at a distance like a trail of Megatheriums , gliding through the darkness .
#Text=The piercing wind made the men hasten their steps , the old man by a semi-rotary motion keeping up with the longer strides and measured tread of the younger .
#Text=When they reached Fourteenth Street , the elder said , " I live but a block from here , " pointing eastward ; " what do you say to a hot toddy ?

#Text=As the old man opened the iron gate , the police officer on the beat passed ; he peered into the faces of the men , and recognizing Sanders , said ,  tough night , sir .

column1: #Text=" All good old gentlemen should be in bed at this hour , " said the officer , lifting one foot after the other in an effort to keep warm , and in so doing showing little terpsichorean grace .
#Text=" It 's only the shank of the evening , officer , " rejoined the old man , as he fumbled with the latch key and finally opened the door .
#Text=The two men entered and the officer passed on .
#Text=Every man has a fad .

#Text=One will tell you he sees nothing in billiards or pool or golf or tennis , but will grow enthusiastic over the scientific possibilities of mumble-peg ; you agree with him , only you substitute " skittles " for " mumble-peg .

#Text=Old Sanders ' fad was mixing toddies and punches .

#Text= The nectar of the gods pales into nothingness when compared with a toddy such as I make , " said he .

column1: #Text=" Ambrosia may have been all right for the degenerates of the old Grecian and Roman days , but an American gentleman demands a toddy -- a hot toddy .

#Text= Men do n't amount to much here , women run everything , " retorted the elder , while he repeated the process of preparing the sugar and gin in the second glass .

column1: #Text=The kettle began to sing .
#Text=" That 's music for you , " chuckled the old man , raising the lid to see if the water had boiled sufficiently .
#Text=" Do you know I think a dinner horn and a singing kettle beat a symphony all hollow for real down-right melody , " and he lifted the kettle from the fire-place .
#Text=Diotti smiled .
#Text=With mathematical accuracy the old man filled the two tumblers with boiling water .
#Text=" Try that , " handing a glass of the toddy to Diotti ; " you will find it all right , " and the old man drew an armchair toward the fire-place , smacking his lips in anticipation .
#Text=The violinist placed his chair closer to the fire and sipped the drink .
#Text=" Your country is noted for its beautiful women ?

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text= We have exquisite types of femininity in Tuscany , " said the young man , with patriotic ardor .

column1: #Text=" Any as fine looking as -- as -- as -- well , say the young lady we dined with to-night ?

#Text= I have no desire to see any one more beautiful , " said the violinist , feeling that the other was trying to draw him out , and determined not to yield .

column1: #Text=" You will pardon the inquisitiveness of an old man , but are not you musicians a most impressionable lot ?

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text= We are human , " answered the violinist .

column1: #Text=" I imagined you were like sailors and had a sweetheart in every port .

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text= That would be a delightful prospect to one having polygamous aspirations , but for myself , one sweetheart is enough , " laughingly said the musician .

column1: #Text=" Only one !

#Text=With this nectar fit for the gods and goddesses of Olympus , let us drink to her ,  said old Sanders , with convivial dignity , his glass raised on high .

#Text= said Diotti ; " we will drink to the first part of that toast , " and holding his glass against that of his bibulous host , continued : " To the dreamy-eyed women of my country , exacting of their lovers ; obedient to their parents and loyal to their husbands , " and his voice rose in sonorous rhythm with the words .
